title: The Courage to Begin Again
sub_title: Embracing the New Year with a Bold Heart
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock had a reputation. Some whispered he was a miser, others that he was simply eccentric. Every New Year's Eve, he'd sit on his porch, bundled in a thick coat despite the cold, watching the town's celebrations with a curious intensity. Children dared each other to wave, often retreating in giggles and shivers when his gaze lingered too long. This year, young Lily, emboldened by a dare and a sliver of courage, approached his porch.

"Happy New Year, Mr. Hemlock!" she called out, her voice trembling slightly. He peered down at her, his eyes, though aged, held a surprising spark. "And what," he rasped, "makes you think it will be happy?" Lily, taken aback, stammered, "Well, it's a new start! A chance to be better!" Hemlock chuckled, a dry, rustling sound. "Courage," he said, more to himself than to her, "it takes courage to believe in new beginnings, especially when the old year leaves its scars." 

He then told Lily a story, a tale not of gold or lost fortunes, but of lost dreams and opportunities squandered due to fear. Fear of failure, fear of judgment, fear of the unknown. He spoke of a life lived cautiously, a life where potential withered on the vine because courage was lacking. As the first fireworks painted the sky, he turned to Lily. "Don't let fear steal your future, child. Embrace the unknown with courage, even if your knees tremble. A new year isn't just a date, it's a chance to rewrite your story." 

Old Man Hemlock's story is a poignant reminder that courage isn't the absence of fear, but the triumph over it. The new year stretches before us, a blank canvas upon which we can paint our dreams, overcome our challenges, and step into the fullness of who God calls us to be. It requires courage to leave behind the comfort of the familiar, to forgive past hurts, and to boldly pursue the purpose He has placed within our hearts. It requires stepping forward even when the path is not clear and trusting that He will guide our steps.
image_description: A snow-covered porch with an old wooden rocking chair, illuminated by the soft glow of a nearby streetlamp reflecting off the snow. No people are visible.
insights: The biblical concept of courage is often linked to trusting in God's presence and power. Joshua 1:9 encourages, "Have I not commanded you? Be strong and courageous. Do not be frightened, and do not be dismayed, for the Lord your God is with you wherever you go." Similarly, Deuteronomy 31:6 urges, "Be strong and courageous. Do not fear or be in dread of them, for it is the Lord your God who goes with you. He will not leave you or forsake you." These verses highlight that our courage is not rooted in our own abilities, but in God's unwavering support and guidance.
prayer: Heavenly Father, as this year comes to a close and a new one begins, I ask for Your courage to face the unknown with faith and hope. Help me to release the fears that hold me back from pursuing Your calling in my life. Fill me with Your strength and wisdom, that I may boldly step into the future, trusting in Your guidance and unwavering love. Grant me the courage to forgive, to try again, to love deeply, and to be a beacon of Your light in the world. In Jesus’ name, I pray. Amen.
reflection: What fears are holding you back from stepping into the new year with courage? What is one small step you can take today to overcome those fears and move forward in faith? How can you better trust in God's presence and power as you navigate the uncertainties of the future?
